title: Learning mechanisms of drug dependence

author: Jennifer Murray, Cambridge Neuroscience, University of Cambridge

segmentation: I'm very grateful to be here today.
It was lovely to get the invitation and I'm excited to talk to you about something that I'm very passionate about.

The combination of information that I'm going to give you today is a little bit different than what I've typically done in the past, so these are two separate streams that I've merged together, and I'm actually picking up from some of my graduate work to discuss today.
Just so I know who I'm speaking to.
Are you clinicians or clinicians in training?
Can you raise your hand for me?
Thank you, are you basic researchers?
OK, human basic research.
An animal basic research.
OK, cool thanks, that helps a lot actually.
Alright I have a pointer and I have a yeah perfect so.
In this talk, I'm going to talk about the development of drug habits, so drug seeking habits, what those are and very brief discussion of what the neural basis of those are.
The impact of environmental cues on drug seeking, and I guess I should also point out that I will be talking about drugs in general.
I will be mixing an information about cocaine, nicotine and alcohol and.

Kind of somewhat assuming that they all act in the same way, which is obviously not the case, but that far exceeds the time constraints here, so there will be a couple of differences pointed out, but I will be basically just lumping them all together as drugs, and then I'll also be talking a little bit about Q exposure therapy.
Not that I do it myself, but the implications based on basic learning theory research.
Four Q exposure therapy and how Q exposure therapy might potentially be improved based on what we've discovered, using basic research in animal models.
So basically this is the cycle of addiction as we see it now.

You transition from use casual, use the occasional drink, the occasional line to abuse regular regular usage that transitions eventually into compulsive drug seeking, in which the behavior is no longer sensitive to the risk of punishments and then periods of abstinence relapse, and then it goes around.

My focus today will be on goal directed drug seeking and habitual drug seeking in particular, so I won't be talking about abstinence or relapse, and I won't be talking about compulsive drug seeking just to Orient you in the addiction cycle.
So we all know that.
Well, I say we all know.
Nothing is experienced in isolation.
A drug experience isn't felt on its own.
There are surrounding stimuli that become paired with that drug experience.

And what's been shown by Nora Volkov in the states at Noida is that if you have cocaine addicts and you show them stimuli associated with cocaine, then you get a hyperactivation of the dopamine system in the caudate.
Betaman, the dorsal part of the striatum and from here on out I will be referring to this as the dorsal striatum.
Using the rodent terminology so dorsal striatum caudate containment.
Same thing.
Kind of.

As.
Drug use transitions from the first exposures.
Whoops, wrong button.

Through use abuse addiction, these drug associated stimuli.

Develop a strength so their their power over the behavior increases and the transition behaviourally has a psychological correlate of shifting from goal directed or action outcome, learning to habitual or stimulus response learning.
And I'll explain that in more detail in just a moment.
And.
We can model this in animals.
So what we do with the routes is on the first few sessions there under a fixed ratio, one schedule of reinforcement.

That means that on the first well, in this case they're put into a chamber and they have a lever in that chamber that will infuse a drug into their circulatory system so they can basically choose to take the drug or not.
If they press the lever, they'll get a cocaine infusion or a drug infusion, and if they don't, they won't get the drug.
So we call that self administration.
And a fixed ratio.
One schedule means that for every lever press they get a drug infusion and we pair this with a light stimulus to make it more similar to the human experience of.
Every drug that we have has some sort of stimulus associated with it.
You can't smoke a cigarette or you can't have nicotine without holding the cigarettes or having the taste of the tobacco in your mouth.
So gradually we increase the response requirements to make it a little bit more challenging for the rats to access the cocaine.

And I work with cocaine right now, so that's why I keep saying cocaine until they get to what we refer to as the 2nd order schedule, and this schedule looks very complicated and I have a diagram here.
It's a fixed interval, 15 fixed ratio, 10 S schedule.
So every 15 minutes.

They receive the cocaine infusion paired with the lights, but within those 15 minutes every 10 lever presses results in just a brief flash of that stimulus, so they get brief light infusions, maintaining their behavior across that 15 minute interval.
So this is a diagram of what a typical fixed interval 15 schedule would look like.
You have again 15 minutes where nothing is there and they can press the lever.
They can turn in circles, they can groom themselves, and nothing is going to happen.
And then 15 minutes in if they press the lever they get the cocaine infusion paired with the light stimulus.
Under the 2nd order schedule, every 10 lever presses during this time will result in a brief presentation of that light stimulus.
And what we've shown.
Is that these presentations?

These contingent presentations of the drug associated condition stimulus maintain high rates of drug seeking during that 15 minute interval before drug is ever in their system, so they will press in this case 150 times in those 15 minutes.
And if we do an omission schedule, where we revert the 2nd order schedule back to a typical fixed interval 15 then their responding.
During that first 15 minute interval declines.
So it drops off and if we return these contingent presentations of the light, then their behavior pops back up again.
So there's something about these cues that are maintaining high rates of drug seeking behavior.
And I have a video here because I like videos.
You can see this rat every time that light flashes.
There have been 10 lever process.
He's very oriented to the light, very much engaged with that and he does that for 15 minutes straight in order to get access to the cocaine so that light is very reinforcing in itself at this point.
So here's a diagram of the psychological processes that are involved.
Early on when training is under a fixed ratio one we we consider that the drug seeking is goal directed.

So the notion of goal directed behavior being that it's a representation of the outcome that is driving the behavior overtime over extended training and under a few conditions that are outside the realm of this presentation.

Stimuli that have been associated with that outcome come to drive behavior an that's known as stimulus, responding or stimulus response behavior so the stimulus can drive the behavior outside of the representation of the outcome.
And I have a lovely example, perhaps of of this in action a man was pulled over for drunk driving and he is being given a breathalyzer.
To test his blood alcohol level.
And apparently the stimulus is a lot like a bottle.
So yes, that stimulus response learning right there or stimulus response behavior.
So typically and drug addiction research, we talk about the MISO limbic dopamine system.
We talk about dopamine levels and the nucleus accumbens.
Driving behavior driving acquisition of drug seeking, that sort of thing, but.

As the behavior transitions from being goal directed to being habitual, there's also a transition in dominance of the dopamine pathway driving that behavior from the Museo limbic to the Niagara Stratel pathways.

And this is our working neurological model right now of the transition from use to drug addiction and it involves a transition from a dominance in the ventral and medial portions of the stratum to the dorsal lateral stride.
And we've tested this.
We've tested the role of dopamine in this region on both goal directed and virtual drug seeking behaviors, so we begin the routzohn Fr one training schedule.
Then gradually move them up to the 2nd order schedule which I've described previously.
And then in the same route.

One schedule of reinforcement, we add a 15 minute interval in order to make it comparable.

Conditioned reinforcer than their behavior.

Once it's habitual, its stimulus driving the behavior and the reinforcer has little to do with it at that point.
So if we devalue the reinforcer.
It should have a greater impact when the reinforcer is what's driving the behavior.
And this was shown by Tony Dickinson back in the early 80s when they did food responding and they had two foods that an animal could respond for fairly equivalently.
And then they devalued one of them by setting them beforehand.
So if you have lots and lots of chocolate, and then you're given the option of chocolate or strawberries, you might go for the strawberries preferentially over the chocolate.
If that's possible.
So.

Early after acquisition of working for food, they devalued one of the reinforcers, and kept and didn't devalue the other, and put these animals back in a chamber and found that the non devalued reinforcer was preferentially worked for.
But after extended training devaluation had no effect on their behavior, suggesting that the behavior was driven by something other than a representation of the outcome.
So this has been tested with cocaine, self administration as well.
In this case they used a seeking taking task in which within the chamber only one lever is ever accessed.
So initially or iaccessible initially the seeking lever is available and they press on the seeking lever in order to gain access to the taking lever.
When they press on the taking lever they get the drug reinforcer and this is trained extensively.
And they learn to press quite a lot on the seeking lever in order to gain access to the taking lever.
After acquisition, the researchers devalued the taking lever by placing the animals under an extinction protocol.
So the animals were placed in the Chamber with only the taking lever.
You could press all they wanted, nothing was going to happen.

Then they put them back in with access to the seeking lever to see what what change may have taken place based on that evaluation, what they found was that after a short cocaine taking history devaluing the taking lever had an impact on seeking labor responding, suggesting a goal directed Ness of that behavior.
But after long training history, there was no impact on the level of seeking following devaluation of the taking link.

In the ventral striatum straight away during training, but in the dorsal lateral straight.
It's something that emerges overtime, so it doesn't occur straight away.

Is very different from having an entire bottle of wine.

Over smoking tobacco feels very different from having just just one cigarette.
So as part of my graduate work, I investigated drugs serving as an interoceptive condition stimulus.

And we used a pavlovi and drug discrimination design, in which on a given day for a given session, rats were either injected with nicotine or with Saline, and then they were placed in an operant chamber where.

Where sucrose was delivered liquid sucrose, so little sips of sugar water was delivered intermittently and non contingently, so they didn't have to press any levers they didn't have to engage in any behavior they could simply access sucrose as it arrived.

So how much were they seeking that sucrose?
How much were they?
I don't want to say aware, but how much were they actively looking for that unconditioned stimulus?
In this case, the sucrose and what we found is.
That rats very quickly learn to distinguish the interceptive state of nicotine from the state of no nicotine.
And they seek the sucrose before it's delivered on nicotine sessions preferentially.
So within two weeks of training easily, these rats were able to use nicotine as an interceptive cue that drove sucrose seeking behavior.
Showing that nicotine can indeed serve as a condition stimulus, and you know, perhaps the human correlate of this being you smoke a cigarette.
At least when I was a teenager, it made you cool.
You have a nice, relaxing morning.
You're you're out with friends, it's making other things better, perhaps, or indicating some sort of positive other positive stimulus in the environment.

So one of the tasks we needed to do was to determine whether this interoceptive stimulus not only behaved like typical exteroceptive stimuli in these sorts of experiments, but also can it compete with an extra receptive stimulus.
So we did this using an overshadowing procedure, and in overshadowing you train 2 elements as a compound.
A compound condition stimulus, and then you test them separately to see how much of the behavioral response is being controlled by 1 compared to the other.
